entries.title: UX Law: Fitts's Law
entries.description: Target size + distance affect interaction time. Application: min-h-11 (44px) for touch targets on mobile
entries.example: min-h-11, min-h-8 (desktop)
entries.counterExample: Buttons <44px on mobile, Tiny click targets

entries.title: UX Law: Hick's Law
entries.description: Decision time increases with number of options. Application: Limit to 5-7 max options
entries.example: Navigation: ≤7 items, Action overflow: ≥4 actions → menu
entries.counterExample: 10+ navigation items, Showing all actions inline

entries.title: UX Law: Miller's Law
entries.description: Working memory holds 7±2 items. Application: Group into chunks of 5-7
entries.example: Form sections: 5-7 fields, Lists: 7 visible items
entries.counterExample: 20 form fields without grouping, Endless lists without pagination

entries.title: UX Law: Doherty Threshold
entries.description: Response time <400ms feels instant. Application: >400ms show loading indicator
entries.example: <100ms instant, >400ms spinner, >1s progress bar
entries.counterExample: No loading state for slow operations, Blocking UI during fetch

entries.title: UX Law: Von Restorff Effect
entries.description: Different items are more memorable. Application: Primary action must be visually distinct
entries.example: variant='default' (filled), variant='outline' (secondary)
entries.counterExample: All buttons look the same, Primary not emphasized

entries.title: UX Law: Jakob's Law
entries.description: Users expect your site to work like others. Application: Follow established conventions
entries.example: Logo top-left, Search top-right, Profile top-right
entries.counterExample: Unconventional layouts, Breaking user expectations

entries.title: UX Law: Goal-Gradient Effect
entries.description: Users accelerate as they approach a goal. Application: Show progress clearly, celebrate milestones, make completion feel achievable
entries.example: Progress bars with percentage, Step X of Y indicators, Completion checkmarks
entries.counterExample: No progress indication, Hidden step count, No milestone feedback

entries.title: UX Law: Peak-End Rule
entries.description: Experiences are judged by peaks and endings. Application: Design memorable moments and strong endings, invest in error recovery
entries.example: Success celebrations, Onboarding completion, Checkout confirmation
entries.counterExample: Abrupt endings, No confirmation feedback, Forgettable experiences

entries.title: UX Law: Serial Position Effect
entries.description: First and last items are remembered best. Application: Place most important items at start or end of lists
entries.example: Primary nav at start/end, Key actions first/last, Important options at edges
entries.counterExample: Critical items buried in middle, Random ordering, No priority placement

entries.title: UX Law: Zeigarnik Effect
entries.description: Incomplete tasks are remembered better than completed ones. Application: Show incomplete progress, use draft indicators, leverage tension
entries.example: Draft badges, Progress indicators, Save reminders, Resume prompts
entries.counterExample: No draft indication, Lost progress, No save prompts

entries.title: UX Law: Aesthetic-Usability Effect
entries.description: Aesthetically pleasing designs are perceived as more usable. Application: Invest in visual polish, consistent styling builds trust
entries.example: Consistent spacing, Harmonious colors, Refined typography, Smooth animations
entries.counterExample: Inconsistent styling, Jarring transitions, Neglected visual details

entries.title: UX Law: Postel's Law
entries.description: Be liberal in what you accept, conservative in what you send. Application: Accept varied input formats, provide clear normalized output
entries.example: Flexible date parsing, Phone format tolerance, Case-insensitive search
entries.counterExample: Rigid input requirements, Rejecting valid variations, No input normalization

entries.title: UX Law: Tesler's Law
entries.description: Complexity cannot be eliminated, only moved. Application: Move complexity to the system, not the user
entries.example: Smart defaults, Auto-detection, Progressive disclosure
entries.counterExample: Exposing system complexity, Too many required fields, No sensible defaults

entries.title: UX Law: Cognitive Load
entries.description: Mental effort is finite - reduce unnecessary cognitive burden. Application: Minimize choices, use recognition over recall, maintain context
entries.example: Clear labels, Visible options, Contextual help, Reduced form fields
entries.counterExample: Information overload, Hidden options, Requiring memorization, Dense layouts

entries.title: UX Law: Occam's Razor
entries.description: The simplest solution is usually the best. Application: Prefer fewer features done well over many features done poorly
entries.example: Minimal props, Single responsibility, Clear purpose
entries.counterExample: Feature bloat, Unnecessary options, Over-engineered solutions

entries.title: Gestalt: Proximity
entries.description: Close elements are perceived as related
entries.example: gap-2 within group, gap-6 between groups

entries.title: Gestalt: Similarity
entries.description: Similar elements are perceived as related
entries.example: Consistent styling for same type

entries.title: Gestalt: Common Region
entries.description: Bounded elements are grouped
entries.example: Cards, Borders, Background containers

entries.title: Gestalt: Prägnanz
entries.description: Simplicity is preferred
entries.example: Reduce visual noise, Clear hierarchy

entries.title: Button color semantics
entries.description: Primary for action, Green for confirmation. primary: Main CTA, Save, Submit, Confirm (not for: Success states); success: Success feedback, status badges, completion (not for: Action buttons); destructive: Delete, Remove, irreversible actions (not for: Warnings); outline: Secondary actions, Cancel, Back (not for: Primary CTA)
entries.why: Green fatigue: If every button is green, users develop blindness; Reserve green for feedback: Success toast has more impact when button wasn't green; Hierarchy > Semantics: Filled vs outline signals primary vs secondary; Industry convention: Apple, Google, Figma use brand color for main CTA

entries.title: Action overflow rule
entries.description: ≤3 actions = Visible buttons | ≥4 actions = Overflow menu
entries.counterExample: 3 actions in menu (hiding unnecessarily); 6 actions as individual buttons (overwhelming)

entries.title: Validation layer: Primitive Components
entries.description: Dumb, reusable, no domain knowledge. Has validation: false. Action: Trust props
entries.context: Analogy: Kitchen utensils (a knife doesn't check if food is fresh)

entries.title: Validation layer: Composite Components
entries.description: Combines primitives, still generic. Has validation: false. Action: Trust props
entries.context: Analogy: Cooking stations (a grill doesn't validate ingredients)

entries.title: Validation layer: Domain Components
entries.description: Domain-aware, API boundary. Has validation: true. Action: Validate here
entries.context: Analogy: The chef (inspects ingredients before cooking, rejects bad ones)

entries.title: Graceful degradation: Show Error Inline
entries.description: Display error indicator in place of bad data. When: Single field invalid

entries.title: Graceful degradation: Show Fallback Value
entries.description: Display safe default with warning. When: Non-critical field

entries.title: Graceful degradation: Show Error Row
entries.description: Entire row highlighted as problematic. When: Multiple fields invalid

entries.title: Graceful degradation: Show Error Boundary
entries.description: Component-level error state. When: Critical failure

entries.title: Status badge: Pending Approval
entries.description: Waiting for review or sign-off. Color: Yellow (Warning). Icon: Clock

entries.title: Status badge: In Progress
entries.description: Work is actively being done. Color: Primary. Icon: Loader

entries.title: Status badge: Completed
entries.description: Work has been finished successfully. Color: Green (Success). Icon: CheckCircle

entries.title: Status badge: Failed/Overdue
entries.description: Past due date or failed state. Color: Red (Error). Icon: AlertTriangle

entries.title: Status badge: Closed/Cancelled
entries.description: Item closed (may or may not be completed). Color: Neutral (Gray). Icon: XCircle

entries.title: Status badge: Deferred/On Hold
entries.description: Postponed for later consideration. Color: Light Gray. Icon: PauseCircle

entries.title: Status badge: Assigned/Scheduled
entries.description: Task has been assigned to someone. Color: Blue (Info). Icon: UserCheck

entries.title: Status badge: Draft
entries.description: Not yet published or finalized. Color: Light Neutral. Icon: FileEdit

entries.title: Status badge: Blocked
entries.description: Cannot proceed due to blocker. Color: Light Error. Icon: Ban

entries.title: Priority badge: Urgent/Critical
entries.description: Color: Red (Error). Icon: AlertOctagon. Animation: pulse

entries.title: Priority badge: High
entries.description: Color: Yellow (Warning). Icon: ArrowUp

entries.title: Priority badge: Medium
entries.description: Color: Blue (Info). Icon: Minus

entries.title: Priority badge: Low
entries.description: Color: Gray (Neutral). Icon: ArrowDown

entries.title: Container selection: 1-3 fields → dialog
entries.description: Complexity: low. Examples: Delete confirmation, Password reset

entries.title: Container selection: 4-7 fields → dialog or sheet
entries.description: Complexity: medium. Examples: Create account, Quick settings

entries.title: Container selection: 8-12 fields → page
entries.description: Complexity: high. Examples: Edit profile, Invoice forms

entries.title: Container selection: 13+ fields → wizard
entries.description: Complexity: very-high. Examples: Onboarding, Multi-step setup

entries.title: Dialog anti-pattern: 11-field form in dialog
entries.description: Problem: Exceeds cognitive capacity. Solution: Use Page

entries.title: Dialog anti-pattern: Multi-step wizard in dialog
entries.description: Problem: Wrong container for complexity. Solution: Use dedicated Wizard

entries.title: Dialog anti-pattern: Primary workflow in dialog
entries.description: Problem: Undervalues importance. Solution: Use Page

entries.title: Dialog anti-pattern: Dialog for data entry > 1 minute
entries.description: Problem: Interruption cost too high. Solution: Use Page

entries.title: UX writing: Buttons & CTAs
entries.description: Use action verbs: Save, Create, Delete. Be specific: "Save Changes" not just "Save". Match button to dialog title. Keep under 3 words
entries.example: Save Changes; Create Project; Delete Item
entries.counterExample: OK; Click Here to Continue; Yes, I Want to Delete This Item

entries.title: UX writing: Error Messages
entries.description: Explain what happened in plain language. Offer a solution. Take responsibility. Be specific
entries.example: We couldn't save your changes. Please try again.; Password must be at least 8 characters with one number.
entries.counterExample: Error: Invalid input; You failed to complete the form correctly

entries.title: UX writing: Empty States
entries.description: Explain why the area is empty. Provide a clear action. Be encouraging. Use illustrations when appropriate
entries.example: No projects yet. Create your first one to get started.; Your inbox is empty. You're all caught up!
entries.counterExample: No data; 0 records found

entries.title: UX writing: Success Messages
entries.description: Celebrate the accomplishment. Be specific about what happened. Include next steps. Use positive language
entries.example: Project created! Ready to add your first task?; Changes saved successfully.
entries.counterExample: Success; Transaction ID: 8492840294

entries.title: UX writing: Form Labels
entries.description: Sentence case: "Email address". Helpful examples: "e.g., john@company.com". Explain requirements upfront. Use placeholder sparingly
entries.example: Label: "Email address" / Helper: "e.g., john@company.com"
entries.counterExample: EMAIL ADDRESS *

entries.title: UX writing: Loading Messages
entries.description: Tell users what's happening. Be reassuring. Provide time estimates. Use active verbs
entries.example: Loading your dashboard...; Processing payment... This usually takes 3-5 seconds.
entries.counterExample: Loading...; Executing database query...

entries.title: UX writing: Warning Messages
entries.description: Clearly state what might go wrong. Explain consequences. Offer alternatives. Use cautious but calm tone
entries.example: Deleting this project will remove all tasks and files. This cannot be undone.
entries.counterExample: WARNING!!! DATA WILL BE LOST!!!

entries.title: UX writing rule: We work for the users
entries.description: They don't work for us

entries.title: UX writing rule: Stay consistent
entries.description: Use consistent terminology

entries.title: UX writing rule: Keep it stress-free
entries.description: Never manipulate or guilt users

entries.title: UX writing rule: Gradual complexity
entries.description: Introduce features one step at a time

entries.title: UX writing rule: Kind over clever
entries.description: Never use passive-aggressive language

entries.title: UX writing rule: Write for all readers
entries.description: Clear language without jargon

entries.title: Container pattern: dialog
entries.description: Use for: Confirmations, Simple forms (1-7 fields), Password entry, Quick creation, <30 sec completion. Fields: 1-7. Complexity: Low

entries.title: Container pattern: page
entries.description: Use for: Complex forms (8+ fields), Primary CRUD, Data entry with sections, >1 minute tasks, Primary workflows. Fields: 8-12. Complexity: High

entries.title: Container pattern: wizard
entries.description: Use for: Multi-step processes, Onboarding, Provisioning, Natural step divisions, 13+ fields. Fields: 13+. Complexity: Very High

entries.title: Container pattern: sheet
entries.description: Use for: Preview/detail views, Mobile interactions, Filters, Desktop Dialog → Mobile Sheet. Fields: Variable. Complexity: Medium

entries.title: Error handling: errorBoundary
entries.description: Use: Catch component crashes.

entries.title: Error handling: loadingStates
entries.description: Use: Show during async operations. >400ms show loading (Doherty Threshold)

entries.title: Error handling: emptyStates
entries.description: Use: No data scenarios.

entries.title: Error handling: errorStates
entries.description: Use: Operation failed.

entries.title: Response time < 100ms: Instant
entries.description: Required feedback: None needed

entries.title: Response time 100-400ms: Slight delay
entries.description: Required feedback: Subtle indicator (disable button, cursor change)

entries.title: Response time > 400ms: Noticeable wait
entries.description: Required feedback: Spinner or skeleton

entries.title: Response time > 1s: Long operation
entries.description: Required feedback: Progress indicator with percentage

entries.title: Response time > 10s: Extended operation
entries.description: Required feedback: Progress bar, status messages, cancel button
